comment._content: Wow. But the apparent poverty is only staggering. Stark contrast to the often dapper ladies and gents in other photos in related sets. Certainly a world away from the relative affluence suggested by the clothes worn by this young fella. (Who was only a short distance and few decades removed). And the mode of dress gives our (light-hearted) "boys wear dresses to avoid kidnap" conversation a few weeks back some extra perspective. (These lads aren't eschewing trousers to avoid kidnap. They simply don't have any. They have rags. Sin é). These kids parents (if they have any) would likely be appalled by our weak bleating at the IMF, NAMA, et al.

comment._content:
Suffering a kind of poor we can't even imagine... yet they seem (at least for now) very happy.
I've seen group photos of poor kids where the attitude was totally different.
And although poor and going trough hardships beyond our wildest imagination, these kids also experienced a freedom we and future generations may never know.
They could run wild, they owned the streets, no mobile phones to call home with, they were trusted to walk to school, look after themselves.
I once interviewed a man who grew up in extreme poverty in the 1930s and he said; "It was only afterwards that we realised we were supposed to have been unhappy."
